questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain following forceful vomiting. Physical examination reveals subcutaneous emphysema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Boerhaave's Syndrome

 

Explanation:

Boerhaave's syndrome is characterized by spontaneous esophageal perforation due to forceful vomiting. Key features include severe chest pain and subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Esophageal perforation

Definition

A breach in the esophageal wall leads to leakage and increased morbidity and mortality

Causes

Iatrogenic injury, spontaneous (Boerhaave's syndrome), foreign bodies, corrosive substances, eosinophilic esophagitis, esophageal cancer

Symptoms
  • Varies by cause and location:
  • Iatrogenic (recent instrumentation)
  • Boerhaave's (vomiting, chest pain, emphysema)
  • Cervical (neck pain, etc.)

Diagnosis

Imaging: Chest X-ray, contrast swallow studies, CT scan

Management
  • Seal perforation, ensure drainage, supportive measures (nutrition, cardiorespiratory support, sepsis control)
  • Conservative Management: Suitable for stable patients: antibiotics, nil by mouth, observation
  • Endoscopic Interventions: Visualization, retrieval, sealing with clips/stents, nasogastric tube placement
  • Surgical Intervention: Required for significant sepsis, large perforations, pleural involvement, delayed presentation
  • Surgical Options: Primary repair, controlled fistula creation, esophageal diversion, esophagectomy (rare)

 

Myocardial Infarction (Option A): Typically presents with chest pain but lacks the association with subcutaneous emphysema. It can sometimes manifest with vomiting.

 

Acute Pancreatitis (Option C): Causes severe abdominal pain radiating to the back, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting, but not chest pain and subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Gastric Ulcer Perforation (Option D): Presents with acute abdominal pain but not typically with subcutaneous emphysema.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with fatigue, difficulty swallowing and pale skin. Investigation reveals a cervical esophageal web. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Plummer-Vinson Syndrome

 

Explanation:

Plummer-Vinson Syndrome is characterized by a cervical esophageal web, iron deficiency anemia, and dysphagia, fitting the patient’s symptoms.

Plummer Vinson Syndrome

Overview
  • A rare condition affecting middle-aged women.
  • Characterized by a triad of the cervical esophageal web, iron deficiency anemia, and dysphagia.
  • Cervical Esophageal Web
    • Thin membrane narrowing the upper esophagus
  • Iron Deficiency Anemia
    • Insufficient iron causes fatigue, shortness of breath, pale skin
  • Dysphagia: Difficulty swallowing

Causes
  • Iron/nutritional deficiencies
  • Genetic factors
  • Autoimmune conditions

Risks
  • Increased risk of post-cricoid and cervical esophageal cancer

Treatment
  • Iron supplements
  • Dietary modifications,
  • Endoscopic dilatation if necessary

 

Achalasia (Option A): Characterized by difficulty swallowing due to failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, not an esophageal web.

 

Barrett’s Esophagus (Option B): Involves changes in the lower esophageal lining, not related to an esophageal web or iron deficiency.

 

Esophageal Carcinoma (Option D): It can cause progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and other symptoms as the tumor grows. However, esophageal carcinoma is not typically associated with the presence of an esophageal web or iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of smoking presents with progressive dysphagia and weight loss. Endoscopy reveals a mass in the mid-esophagus. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Imaging shows the tumor invading the muscularis propria and metastasis to three regional lymph nodes. What is the TNM classification for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) T2 N2 M0

 

Explanation:

T2 N2 M0 indicates tumor invasion of the muscularis propria (T2), metastasis to 3-6 regional lymph nodes (N2), and no distant metastasis (M0).

 

TNM Staging- Carcinoma Esophagus

T

Tx

Tumor cannot be assessed

T0

No primary tumor

Tis

High-grade dysplasia (malignant cells confined by basement membrane)

T1

Tumor invades lamina propria, muscularis mucosae, or submucosa

T1a

Invades lamina propria or muscularis mucosae

T1b

Invades submucosa

T2

Invades muscularis propria

T3

Invades adventitia

T4

Invades adjacent structures

T4a

Invades pleura, pericardium, azygos vein, diaphragm, or peritoneum

T4b

Invades aorta, vertebral body, or airway

N

Nx

Nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional node metastasis

N1

Metastasis in 1-2 regional nodes

N2

Metastasis in 3-6 regional nodes

N3

Metastasis in 7+ regional nodes

M

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

 

T2 N1 M0 (Option A): Incorrect nodal stage (N1: 1-2 nodes)

 

T3 N2 M0 (Option C): Incorrect tumor stage (T3: invades adventitia)

 

T2 N3 M1 (Option D): Incorrect nodal (N3: 7+ nodes) and metastasis stage (M1: distant metastasis)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia for both solids and liquids over the past year. He also reports occasional chest pain, especially after eating. Manometry is performed and analyzed using the Chicago Classification. The results show spastic contractions in the distal esophagus. Based on these findings, what type of achalasia is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Type III Achalasia

 

Explanation:

Chicago Classification 4.0

 

Revised Criteria for Esophageal Disorders:

 

Esophageal Disorder

Description

Values

1. Achalasia

Type I

Minimal contractility (Option A ruled out)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, 100% failed peristalsis

Type II

Esophageal pan-pressurization (Option B ruled out)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, 100% failed peristalsis with ≥ 20% pan-esophageal pressurization

Type III

Spastic contractions (Option C)

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, ≥ 20% spastic contractions (DCI > 8,000 mmHg·s·cm)

2. Esophagogastric Junction Outflow Obstruction (EGJOO)

Elevated integrated relaxation pressure (IRP) with preserved peristalsis

IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, some preserved peristalsis

3. Distal Esophageal Spasm (DES)

Premature (rapid) contractions with normal IRP (Option D ruled out)

Normal IRP, ≥ 20% premature contractions (DL < 4.5 s)

4. Hypercontractile (Jackhammer) Esophagus

Extremely strong peristaltic contractions

Normal IRP, ≥ 20% hypercontractile contractions (DCI > 8,000 mmHg·s·cm)

5. Ineffective Esophageal Motility (IEM)

Weak or failed peristalsis

Normal IRP, > 50% ineffective swallows (DCI < 450 mmHg·s·cm for weak peristalsis)

6. Absent Contractility

Complete lack of esophageal contractility

Normal IRP, 100% failed peristalsis

 

IRP: Integrated Relaxation Pressure

DCI: Distal Contractile Integral

DL: Distal Latency

questions.text: A 40-year-old man complains of a burning sensation in his chest and regurgitation after meals. Symptoms improve with antacids and have no significant weight loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

 

Explanation:

GERD is a condition where stomach contents, including acid, reflux into the esophagus, causing symptoms like heartburn, regurgitation, difficulty swallowing and sometimes chest pain. The burning sensation behind the sternum after meals, improvement with antacids, and the absence of significant weight loss are classic signs of GERD, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.



 

Pathophysiology:

  • Lower Esophageal Sphincter (LES) Dysfunction: Muscle is weak or relaxes inappropriately, allowing stomach acid to flow back into the esophagus.
  • Esophageal Motility Disorders: Reduced peristalsis (movement) in the esophagus
  • Increased Intra-abdominal Pressure
  • Delayed Gastric Emptying: Slow emptying of the stomach can increase acid exposure in the esophagus.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Heartburn
  • Regurgitation
  • Dysphagia
  • Chest Pain

 

Diagnosis:

  • Endoscopy: To visualize the esophagus and identify inflammation, ulcers, or Barrett's esophagus.
  • 24-hour pH Monitoring: Gold standard for diagnosis of GERD which measures acid exposure in the esophagus over a day.
  • Esophageal Manometry: Assesses esophageal motility and LES function.
  • Barium Swallow: An X-ray test that evaluates swallowing and reflux patterns.

 

Peptic ulcer disease (Option A): Causes abdominal pain or discomfort, often related to meals, but usually does not cause regurgitation. Antacids can provide relief but are not a primary treatment.

 

Gastritis (Option C): Involves inflammation of the stomach lining, leading to nausea, abdominal pain, and discomfort, but not typically associated with regurgitation.

 

Esophageal spasm (Option D): Causes chest pain and difficulty swallowing, not commonly associated with heartburn or regurgitation that improves with antacids.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are diagnostic of nutcracker esophagus?


	Distal esophageal contraction amplitude > 180 mmHg
	Distal esophageal contraction amplitude > 45 mmHg
	Distal esophageal peristaltic wave duration > 6 cm
	Distal esophageal contraction amplitude < 30 mmHg
	Distal esophageal contraction duration > 6 seconds
	Multiple simultaneous contractions with an amplitude of > 30 mmHg.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1 and 5

 

Explanation:

 

Hypercontractile motility disorder

Nutcracker/ Jackhammer Esophagus

 

Definition

Excessively intense, coordinated esophageal contractions with normal LES function.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia (solids and liquids)
  • Severe chest pain
  • Less common regurgitation
  • Globus sensation

Investigations

Esophageal Manometry
  • High amplitude contractions (>180 mmHg)
  • Prolonged contraction duration (>6 seconds)
  • Normal LES pressure and relaxation

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

"Corkscrew" or "rosary bead" appearance due to intense contractions

Endoscopy

Typically normal mucosa

Used to rule out structural abnormalities

Management

Non-Pharmacological

Dietary Modifications: Smaller, frequent meals

Pharmacological
  • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., nifedipine)
  • Nitrates (e.g., isosorbide dinitrate)
  • Botulinum Toxin Injection

Surgical
  • Esophageal Myotomy (rare)
  • Peroral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM)
  • Severe cases may require Esophagectomy

Endoscopic

Dilation (less effective)

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with its endoscopy images


 


	
		
			
			A) Esophageal candidiasis
			
			
			1)
			
		
		
			
			B) Feline esophagitis
			
			
			2)
			
		
		
			
			C)Herpes simplex esophagitis
			
			
			3)
			
		
		
			
			D)CMV esophagitis
			
			
			4)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2

 

Esophageal candidiasis

 

Characterized by white, raised plaques that resemble cottage cheese or curd. These plaques are adherent and often found along the entire length of the esophagus. The surrounding mucosa may appear erythematous and friable.

Feline esophagitis

 

Often presents with concentric rings, giving the esophagus a "feline" appearance,

Herpes simplex esophagitis

 

Typically presents with multiple small, well-circumscribed, punched-out ulcers. These ulcers are often located in the mid-to-distal esophagus. The surrounding mucosa may be erythematous.

CMV esophagitis

 

Characterized by large, solitary or linear ulcers, often located in the mid-to-distal esophagus. The ulcers may have a well-defined border and are surrounded by relatively normal mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the esophagus?

choices.text: The upper esophageal sphincter is composed of the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus muscles
The lower esophageal sphincter is a physiological entity
The cervical esophagus is supplied by the inferior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All are true

 

Explanation:

Upper esophageal sphincter (UES):

Feature

Details

Location

The inlet of the esophagus, at the neck

Muscle Composition

Inferior pharyngeal constrictor composed of the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus muscles (Option A)

Weakness Point

The transition between the thyropharyngeus (oblique fibers) and cricopharyngeus (horizontal fibers) creates the Killian triangle (site of Zenker diverticulum)

 

Lower esophageal sphincter (LES):

Feature

Details

Location

The lower end of the esophagus, in the terminal 4 cm

Function

Prevents reflux of gastric and duodenal contents

Specialty

A physiological zone of high pressure (Option B)


 

Vasculature:

Segment

Arterial Supply

Venous Drainage

Cervical Esophagus

Inferior thyroid arteries (Option C)

Inferior thyroid veins

Thoracic Esophagus

Descending thoracic aorta, bronchial arteries

Azygos and hemiazygos veins

Abdominal Esophagus

Left gastric artery, paired inferior phrenic arteries

Drains into systemic and portal venous systems via left and right phrenic veins, left gastric (coronary) vein, and short gastric veins

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient complains of intermittent dysphagia and episodes of food obstruction. Endoscopy reveals a fibrous band at the gastroesophageal junction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Schatzki Ring

 

Explanation:

Schatzki ring is identified as a benign constricting band of fibrous tissue at the gastroesophageal junction, causing symptoms such as dysphagia and food obstruction.

 

Schatzki Ring

Overview
  • A benign constricting band of fibrous tissue located at the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ).
  • Characteristics
    • Proximal side lined with squamous epithelium
    • The distal side lined with columnar epithelium

Causes
  • Exact cause unclear
  • Linked to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
  • Often associated with hiatal hernia

Symptoms
  • Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing)
  • Food obstruction

Diagnosis
  • Barium esophagram
  • Endoscopy

Treatment
  • Endoscopic dilation using bougie or balloon
  • Biopsy to rule out malignancy
  • Repeated dilation may be necessary for symptomatic relief

 

Esophageal Web (Option A): Typically found in the upper esophagus and associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome, not at the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Zenker's Diverticulum (Option B): A pharyngeal pouch causing dysphagia but located in the upper esophagus or throat, it is not a band at the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Barrett's Esophagus (Option C): Involves metaplasia of the esophageal lining due to chronic GERD, not a constricting band.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with late-onset difficulty swallowing and significant weight loss. Imaging reveals an aberrant right subclavian artery compressing the esophagus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dysphagia Lusoria

 

Explanation:

Dysphagia lusoria is caused by vascular compression of the esophagus due to an aberrant right subclavian artery, fitting the patient's symptoms and imaging findings.

 

Dysphagia Lusoria

Definition

Rare swallowing disorder due to vascular compression of the esophagus, mainly by an aberrant right subclavian artery (ARSA)

Pathophysiology

ARSA from the left aortic arch passes behind/in front of the esophagus, causing compression

Symptoms

Difficulty swallowing worsens with age, possible weight loss and nutritional deficiencies

Diagnosis
  • Imaging studies (barium swallow, chest CT)
  • Manometric studies are not typically helpful

Management

Based on symptom severity

  • Dietary modifications for mild cases.
  • Surgical intervention for severe cases.

 


 

 

Symptom Severity

Management Approach

Mild to Moderate
  • Lifestyle and dietary modifications:
    • Avoid exacerbating foods, eat slower, chew well, take smaller bites, sip liquids,
    • Reassurance
  • Medications
    • Acid suppression (proton pump inhibitors), promotility agents (cisapride)

Severe or Refractory
  • Surgical Intervention
    • Remove aberrant vessel, reconstruct position
  • Surgical Methods
    • Median sternotomy, cervical approach, possible severing without reconstruction
  • Surgical Complications
    • Damage to nearby structures, altered blood flow to right upper extremity

Non-Surgical
  • Endoscopic dilation (palliative): Temporary relief of dysphagia
  • Interventional radiology: Endovascular ligation of aberrant vessel while maintaining blood flow

 

Achalasia (Option A): Involves esophageal motility disorder, not typically associated with vascular compression.

 

Esophageal Cancer (Option B): Can cause dysphagia and weight loss, but no vascular anomaly.

 

Schatzki's Ring (Option D): Causes dysphagia but is related to a mucosal ring at the gastroesophageal junction, not vascular compression.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man undergoes an endoscopy for evaluation of dysphagia and an incidental mass is discovered in the esophagus. An endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) shows a hypoechoic mass originating from the muscularis propria. Which of the following statements regarding the esophageal lesion is most accurate?

choices.text: Immediate biopsy and fine-needle aspiration (FNA) should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
If the lesion is asymptomatic and small, it can be observed without biopsy.
The preferred treatment for small, symptomatic lesions is chemotherapy.
Large lesions (>5 cm) are best managed with radiofrequency ablation (RFA)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer:

B) If the lesion is asymptomatic and small, it can be observed without biopsy.

 

Explanation:

The clinical scenario is suggestive of leiomyoma.

Small, asymptomatic leiomyomas can be safely observed without biopsy.


 

Esophageal Leiomyomas

Overview
  • Hypoechoic masses beneath the mucosa, typically found in the middle to distal esophagus
  • Most common benign tumor in the esophagus
  • Often found incidentally during endoscopies

Origin

Arise from the muscularis propria or submucosal layer

Symptoms

Usually asymptomatic, but large tumors can cause dysphagia or discomfort

Imaging
  • Barium esophagram: Smooth filling defect
  • Endoscopy: Round protrusion with smooth overlying mucosa
  • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS): Hypoechoic with regular borders, originating from the fourth endosonographic layer

Malignant Transformation

Rare, resection is recommended if enlargement is observed during follow-up

Biopsy

Biopsies or FNAs are relatively contraindicated due to risk of scarring, which complicates enucleation (Option A ruled out)

Surgical Approaches
  • Enucleation: Thoracoscopic approach for smaller tumors. Chemotherapy is not indicated (Option C ruled out)
  • Submucosal Tunneling Endoscopic Resection (STER): Minimally invasive, involves creating a submucosal tunnel for resection
  • Thoracoscopy: Suitable for larger tumors (>5 cm) (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with progressive dysphagia and weight loss over the past 3 months. An endoscopy reveals a tumor in the lower third of the esophagus. Biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma. Further investigation reveals, the tumor has invaded the muscularis propria but no distant metastasis is detected. Which treatment option is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Esophagectomy

 

Explanation:

Esophagectomy is the primary treatment for locally advanced esophageal cancer where the tumor has invaded the muscularis propria.

 

Carcinoma Esophagus- Management

Staging
  • Accurate staging is essential for treatment planning.

Early-Stage Disease
  • Endoscopic Mucosal Resection (EMR): Removes superficial cancers (T1a) and early cancers with minimal submucosal invasion (T1b). (Option A ruled out)
  • Endoscopic Submucosal Dissection (ESD): Removes larger lesions with en bloc resection. (Option B ruled out)
  • Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA): Treats early Barrett's esophagus-associated cancers. Uses heat to destroy cancer cells. No surgical specimen for pathological assessment. (Option D ruled out)

Locally Advanced Disease
  • Esophagectomy: Primary treatment for locally advanced cancer. Removes esophagus and reconstructs the digestive tract using the stomach, jejunum, or colon. Surgical approaches: transhiatal, transthoracic, minimally invasive (MIE). (Option C)
  • Multimodality Therapy: Combines chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and surgery.
  • Neoadjuvant Chemoradiation: Shrinks the tumor before surgery. CROSS trial showed survival benefit for neoadjuvant chemoradiation followed by surgery.

Palliative Treatment
  • Endoscopic Stenting: Maintains esophageal patency, helps with swallowing difficulties.
  • Chemotherapy: Slows cancer progression, shrinks the tumor.
  • Radiotherapy: Shrinks tumors, controls bleeding.
  • Brachytherapy: Internal radiation therapy targeting the tumor.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of smoking and heavy alcohol consumption presents with progressive dysphagia and significant weight loss. Endoscopy reveals an ulcerated lesion in the mid-esophagus, and biopsies confirm squamous cell carcinoma. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic step to assess the extent of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Endoscopic Ultrasound (EUS)

 

Explanation:

Endoscopic Ultrasound (EUS) is the most accurate method for assessing the T stage of the primary tumour and the involvement of surrounding lymph nodes.

 

Carcinoma Esophagus - Risk factors, clinical features, investigations

Types
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma
  • Adenocarcinoma

Risk Factors
  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma: Smoking, Alcohol, Hot beverages, N-nitroso foods,
  • Adenocarcinoma: Obesity, Gastroesophageal reflux, Barrett's esophagus

Clinical Features
  • Progressive dysphagia, Anorexia, Weight loss, Odynophagia, Regurgitation.
  • Advanced symptoms: Hoarseness, Aspiration, Choking, etc.

Investigation
  • Endoscopy: Tumor visualization, Biopsies, Chromoendoscopy , NBI
  • Barium contrast study: Tumor as ulcerated/stenotic lesion
  • Bronchoscopy: Check airway spread
  • Endoscopic & Percutaneous Ultrasonography:
    • EUS for staging tumor (T stage) and paraesophageal nodes (Option C)
    • Percutaneous ultrasound of cervical nodes with FNA
  • CT scan: Distant node assessment
  • FDG-PET scan: Detects nodes/metastases, not for tumor staging

 

Chromoendoscopy(Option A): Used for enhancing visualization of mucosal lesions in early diagnosis but not for staging.

 

Barium contrast study(Option B): Helps visualize the tumor as an ulcerated or stenotic lesion but does not provide staging information.

 

FDG-PET scan(Option D): Useful for detecting nodal involvement and metastases but not for primary tumor staging.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a 10-year history of chronic GORD presents for a follow-up endoscopy. The endoscopy shows a 3 cm segment of salmon-colored mucosa extending above the OGJ with biopsy-proven intestinal metaplasia. He has no nodularity or ulceration. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: High-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and aspirin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) High-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and aspirin

 

Explanation:

Endoscopy findings are consistent with Barrett’s Esophagus. High-dose PPI therapy can reduce acid reflux and allow for mucosal healing, while aspirin has been shown to have a chemopreventive effect. This combination can improve outcomes in Barrett's esophagus.

 

Barrett's Esophagus

Definition

Complication of GORD

Columnar epithelium >1 cm above OGJ

Endoscopic Landmarks

OGJ: proximal end of gastric folds, not diaphragmatic pinch/squamocolumnar junction

Classification

Prague C&M: circumferential (C) and maximal (M) extent

Risk Factors
  • Chronic GORD
  • Age >50
  • Smoking
  • Central obesity
  • Male

Cancer Risk
  • Non-dysplastic: 0.2–0.5%/year
  • Low-grade: 0.7%/year
  • High-grade: 7%/year

Screening
  • Early identification/treatment

Treatment
  • Treat underlying GORD, same pharmacological therapy as symptomatic GORD
  • Chemoprevention: Aspirin + high-dose PPI improves outcomes (Option C)
  • Dysplastic Treatment: Ablate/resect without invasive cancer, controversial in non-dysplastic
  • Ablative Therapy: Flat lesions only, RFA preferred
  • EMR vs ESD
    • EMR: easier, piecemeal;
    • ESD: en bloc, better margins

Post-Treatment

Surveillance for recurrence/persistent Barrett's or neoplasia


 

Annual surveillance endoscopy (Option A): Surveillance intervals depend on dysplasia grade; no dysplasia was detected here.

 

Immediate endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) (Option B): Not indicated without evidence of nodularity or high-grade dysplasia.

 

Endoscopic ablation with RFA (Option D): Considered if there is dysplasia; no dysplasia here.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with intermittent chest pain and difficulty swallowing for the past few months. The chest pain is often severe and mimics angina but is not related to exertion. His symptoms often occur at night. Barium swallow reveals a typical finding given below. Which of the following disorders is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Diffuse esophageal spasm

 

Explanation:

 

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm (DES)

 

Definition

Uncoordinated, simultaneous contractions of the esophagus with normal LES function.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia (solids and liquids)
  • Severe chest pain
  • Less common regurgitation
  • Globus sensation

Investigations

Esophageal Manometry: Multiple simultaneous non-peristaltic contractions with an amplitude of > 30 mmHg; normal LES pressure and relaxation.
 

Barium Swallow (Esophagram): "Corkscrew" or "Rosary bead" appearance.

(Option A)
 

Endoscopy: Generally normal mucosa; rule out structural abnormalities.

Management

Non-Pharmacological: Dietary Modifications (smaller, frequent meals)
 

Pharmacological:

  • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., nifedipine)
  • Nitrates (e.g., isosorbide dinitrate)
  • Botulinum Toxin Injection
 

Surgical:

  • Esophageal Myotomy (rare)
  • Peroral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM)
 

Endoscopic: Dilation (less effective)

 

Achalasia cardia (Option A): Achalasia is characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax and the absence of normal peristalsis in the esophagus. Patients typically present with progressive dysphagia for both solids and liquids, regurgitation of undigested food, and chest pain. A barium swallow in achalasia usually shows a “bird beak” appearance, not a corkscrew pattern.

 

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) (Option B): GERD is a condition where the LES allows stomach acid to reflux into the esophagus, causing heartburn and regurgitation. While GERD can cause esophagitis and strictures, it does not cause a corkscrew appearance on a barium swallow.

 

Esophageal stricture (Option C) are narrowing of the esophagus often caused by chronic GERD, leading to progressive dysphagia. On a barium swallow, strictures usually appear as a narrowed segment of the esophagus but do not create a corkscrew pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a minimally invasive procedure for treating achalasia cardia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Per-Oral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM)

 

Explanation:

Management of achalasia cardia

Management

Description

Pharmacological Treatments
  • Calcium Channel Blockers

Reduce LES pressure.
  • Nitrates

Relax the LES.
  • 5'-Phosphodiesterase Inhibitors

Increase cyclic GMP to lower LES pressure.
  • Botulinum Toxin (Botox) Injections

Temporarily paralyze LES muscles.

Non-Surgical Interventions
  • Bougie/Balloon Dilatation

Ruptures LES muscle fibers to reduce pressure.

Surgical Treatments
  • Laparoscopic Heller's Cardiomyotomy

(Most common)

Incision in LES muscle to reduce pressure.

It is often combined with a fundoplication. (Option A ruled out)
  • Partial Fundoplication

Prevents reflux; options include Dor or Toupet fundoplication. (Option B ruled out)

Endoscopic Treatments
  • Per-Oral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM)

Newer Minimally invasive procedure involving dissection of LES muscle fibers. (Option C)

 

Management of Chronic Cases
  • Megaesophagus

Severe cases may require esophagectomy (surgical removal of the esophagus). (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia for liquids more than solids over six months, regurgitation of undigested food, nocturnal cough, and unintentional weight loss. Which investigation is the gold standard for diagnosing his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) High-resolution manometry

Explanation:

 

Achalasia cardia

 

Definition

It is characterized by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall. This leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus. (Option A)

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance).

 


 

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris, It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia such as tumors.


 

Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (Option A): Useful for ruling out mechanical obstructions or esophageal pathologies, but not the gold standard for diagnosing achalasia.

 

Barium swallow study (Option C): Reveals classic signs like the "bird-beak" appearance, but lacks the specificity of manometry for assessing esophageal motility.

 

Chest X-ray (Option D): Not typically used for diagnosing achalasia; may show indirect signs but lacks detailed diagnostic information.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the Zenker’s diverticulum?

choices.text: An enlarged diverticulum always results in desynchronization.
Halitosis is a symptom of an enlarged diverticulum.
Protrudes posteriorly below the cricopharyngeal sphincter.
Absence of a suture line increases the chance of a postoperative leak.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Halitosis is a symptom of an enlarged diverticulum.

 

Explanation:

Halitosis, or bad breath, can occur with an enlarged Zenker's diverticulum. This is due to food becoming trapped in the pouch and decomposing, leading to foul-smelling breath. This symptom is a direct result of the diverticulum filling with food, making this statement correct.

 

An enlarged diverticulum always results in desynchronization (Option A): While desynchronization between pharyngeal contraction and the opening of the upper esophageal sphincter is a key factor in the formation of Zenker's diverticulum, it is not accurate to state that an enlarged diverticulum always results in desynchronization. As the diverticulum enlarges, symptoms usually are food trapping and regurgitation.

 

Protrudes posteriorly below the cricopharyngeal sphincter (Option C): Zenker's diverticulum protrudes posteriorly above the cricopharyngeal sphincter, not below it. The diverticulum emerges through a natural weak point known as the dehiscence of Killian, located above the cricopharyngeal muscle.

 

Absence of a suture line increases the chance of a postoperative leak (Option D): The absence of a suture line decreases the risk of a postoperative leak



 

Zenker Diverticulum:

  • False pulsion diverticulum as it protrudes posteriorly above the cricopharyngeal sphincter through the dehiscence of Kilian between the oblique and horizontal fibres of the inferior pharnygeal constrictor.
  • It is due to loss of coordination between pharyngeal contraction and opening of the upper esophagal sphincter.

 

Clinical features

  • When the diverticulum is small, symptoms largely reflect desynchronization of swallowing with pharyngeal dysphagia.
  • As the pouch enlarges:

- The fundus descends into the

mediastinum.

- Regurgitation of trapped food can occur

and lead to aspiration.

- Main symptom is halitosis.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Barium Swallow Study (Esophagram): To visualize the esophagus and identify the presence of a diverticulum.

 

  • Esophagal Manometry
  • MRI
  • Endoscopy

Surgical treatment :

  • Diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeus myotomy
  • Diverticular suspension: The diverticulum is dissected and absence of a suture line lessens the chance of a postoperative leak.
  • Cricopharyngeus myotomy
  • Newer techniques: Transoral introduction of a linear stapler.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with persistent GERD symptoms despite optimal medical therapy is considered for surgery. What is the most appropriate surgical procedure for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nissen fundoplication

 

Explanation:

  • Nissen fundoplication is the preferred surgical treatment for GERD when medical management fails.
  • It involves wrapping the upper part of the stomach around the lower esophagus to increase the pressure at the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), reducing reflux.
  • This procedure effectively controls GERD symptoms and is typically recommended for patients like this woman with persistent symptoms despite optimal medical therapy.

 

Management of GERD:

Lifestyle Changes:

  • Elevate the head of the bed
  • Avoid lying down after meals
  • Quit smoking:

 

Medical Management:

  • Antacids: Neutralize stomach acid
  • H2-receptor antagonists: Ranitidine, Famotidine
  • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs): Omeprazole, Esomeprazole

 

Surgical Options:

 

Antireflux operation: 3 components

  • Restoration of intra abdominal segment of the esophagus
  • Crural repair
  • Reinforcement of the LES by the upper stomach or prosthesis.

 

Fundoplication: A surgical procedure to wrap the top of the stomach around the lower esophagus to strengthen the sphincter.

 

  • Complete fundoplication(Nissen)
  • Partial fundoplication: Posteriorly (Toupet) or Anteriorly(Dor, Watson) has few short-term side effects but has a higher long-term failure rate.
  • Transoral Incisionless Fundoplication (TIF): An endoscopic procedure performed through the mouth but may be less effective for severe GERD and not suitable for all patients.
  • Magnetic Sphincter Augmentation (LINX Device): Involves implanting a ring of magnetic beads around the lower esophageal sphincter to enhance its function and prevent reflux.

Magnetic Sphincter Augmentation (LINX Device): Involves implanting a ring of magnetic beads around the lower esophageal sphincter to enhance its function and prevent reflux.

 

The Fontan procedure(Option B) is a cardiac surgery used to treat congenital heart defects that affect blood flow through the heart. It is not related to GERD management and is therefore not appropriate.

 

The Hartmann procedure (Option C) is a type of bowel surgery often used for conditions like diverticulitis or colorectal cancer. It involves removing a portion of the colon and creating a colostomy. This procedure has no role in the treatment of GERD.

 

Heineke–Mikulicz pyloroplasty (Option D) is a surgical procedure performed to widen the pyloric sphincter, usually to treat conditions like pyloric stenosis. It does not address the symptoms or pathophysiology of GERD and is therefore not appropriate for this patient's condition.

questions.text: Which hormone is known to decrease LES pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Progesterone

 

Explanation:

Lower Esophageal Sphincter (LES) is a muscle at the end of the esophagus where it meets the stomach. It helps prevent stomach acid and contents from flowing back into the esophagus.

 

  • Under normal conditions the LES remains tonically contracted with an intra luminal pressure of about 30mm Hg.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient reports chronic heartburn and difficulty swallowing. An upper endoscopy shows a part of the stomach protruding through the diaphragm. Which condition is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hiatus hernia

 

Explanation:

 

Hiatus Hernia: Condition in which the abdominal contents pass through the hiatal opening of the diaphragm into the mediastinum.

 

Types

Description

Type I/Sliding Hiatus Hernia

The most common type. The gastroesophageal junction and part of the stomach slide up through the diaphragm.

Type II/Paraesophageal Hiatus Hernia

Part of the stomach pushes through the diaphragm next to the esophagus. The gastroesophageal junction remains in place.

Type III/Mixed Hiatus Hernia

Combines features of both sliding and paraesophageal hernias.

Type IV

Involves viscera other than the stomach in the hernial sac like colon

Clinical Features: Heartburn, regurgitation of food, chest pain


 

Diagnosis: Barium swallow X-Ray, Esophageal manometry

 

Treatment: PPI, Nissen Fundoplication, Hernia repair

 

Peptic ulcer disease (Option A): It is characterized by the development of sores or ulcers in the lining of the stomach or the first part of the small intestine (duodenum). While it may cause symptoms similar to heartburn, it is not associated with the protrusion of stomach contents through the diaphragm.

 

Esophageal cancer (Option C) presents with symptoms like difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), unintended weight loss, and chest pain. Unlike a hiatus hernia, esophageal cancer does not involve a diaphragmatic hernia but rather a malignant growth within the esophagus.

 

Gastritis (Option D) refers to the inflammation of the stomach lining, often due to factors like H. pylori infection, chronic alcohol use, or prolonged NSAID use. While it can cause symptoms like epigastric pain, nausea, and heartburn, it does not involve any protrusion of the stomach through the diaphragm.

questions.text: A newborn male presents with severe respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen. Chest X-ray reveals bowel loops in the left thoracic cavity. Immediate surgical intervention is planned to repair the diaphragmatic defect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bochdalek hernia

 

Explanation:

  • Bochdalek hernia is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), accounting for about 90% of cases.
  • The clinical presentation typically includes severe respiratory distress, a scaphoid abdomen, and bowel sounds in the chest, as seen in this patient.
  • A chest X-ray often reveals bowel loops in the thoracic cavity, and immediate surgical repair is necessary. It is usually found on the left side (80%), but can also occur on the right (15%) or be bilateral (5%).


 

Aspect

Details

Description

Failure of fusion of pleuroperitoneal canal, leading to direct communication between pleura and peritoneum on the left side

Common Contents

Colon, occasionally small bowel or stomach

Associated Conditions
  • Hypoplasia (potentially bilateral)
  • Decreased bronchial branch generation
  • Extension of tunica media beyond respiratory bronchioles
  • Decreased total lung mass

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory embarrassment
  • Scaphoid abdomen
  • Bowel sounds on the left side of the chest
  • Mediastinal shift towards the right side
  • Intestinal obstruction

 

Morgagni hernia (Option B):

  • It is a less common type of diaphragmatic hernia, typically located between the sternal and costal attachments of the diaphragm, in the anterior part of the chest.
  • It is more often right-sided, with the colon being the most common herniated content.
  • Unlike Bochdalek hernias, Morgagni hernias are usually asymptomatic. The absence of respiratory distress and the typical posterior location of bowel loops on imaging differentiate it from Bochdalek hernia.

 

Rolling Hiatus Hernia (Option C):

  • It involves the stomach or other abdominal organs herniating through the esophageal hiatus alongside the esophagus. Symptoms can include gastroesophageal reflux, chest pain, and dysphagia, but it is unlikely to cause the severe respiratory distress seen in congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
  • It does not present with bowel loops in the thoracic cavity, which distinguishes it from Bochdalek hernia.

 

Sliding Hiatus Hernia (Option D):

  • It occurs when the gastroesophageal junction and part of the stomach slide up into the chest through the esophageal hiatus. Like the rolling hiatus hernia, it is more common in adults and is associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • It does not cause respiratory distress or involve the herniation of bowel loops into the thoracic cavity, making it less likely in this scenario.

questions.text: A newborn male, 1 day old, presents with persistent regurgitation of feeds and continuous drooling of saliva from the mouth. The baby exhibits frequent coughing and cyanosis, prompting an investigation that reveals a tracheoesophageal fistula. Which type is the most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Type C

 

Explanation:

 

Tracheoesophageal fistula(TOF):


 

Type C Tracheoesophageal fistula

Aspect

Details

Most common type

85% are blind upper end with lower end communicating with the trachea(Type C); associated with VACTER anomalies

VACTER Anomalies
  • V - Vertebral defects
  • A - Anal atresia
  • C - Cardiac defect (e.g., pulmonary stenosis)
  • T - Tracheoesophageal fistula
  • R - Radial hypoplasia and renal agenesis

Symptoms (Option C)
  • Regurgitation
  • Drooling
  • Cough
  • Cyanosis
  • Often associated with maternal hydramnios (50%).

Investigations
  • Nasogastric tube obstruction
  • Contrast study
  • Chest X-ray
  • Echocardiography

Treatment

Surgical intervention


 

Type A (Option A): Esophageal atresia without any fistulous connection to the trachea. The esophagus ends in a blind pouch. Symptoms include the inability to swallow or feed, which are not seen in this patient.

 

Type B (Option B): Esophageal atresia with a fistula between the proximal esophagus and trachea. Rare (1% of cases) and less likely to cause regurgitation since the lower esophagus is not involved.


Type E (Option D): H-type fistula without esophageal atresia. Symptoms like choking and coughing are milder and may lead to delayed diagnosis. The absence of esophageal atresia doesn't fit the persistent regurgitation and drooling in this patient.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man ingests a household cleaner and sustains a corrosive injury to esophagus. Which of the following is false in this case?

choices.text: Neutralization with vinegar/citrus for alkali; antacids/milk/egg whites for acid
Avoid emetics and sodium bicarbonate to prevent perforation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Early endoscopy is not preferred

 

Explanation:

Early endoscopy is advised to assess severity and extent

Corrosive injury to the esophagus happens on ingestion of acids or alkalis

 

Aspect

Details

Pathophysiology
  • Alkali causes liquefaction, saponification, and thrombosis of vessels, leading to fibrosis and stricture
  • Acid causes intense pylorospasm, antral pooling, coagulation necrosis, and eschar formation

Acute Phase Management
  • Neutralization: vinegar/citrus for alkali; antacids/milk/egg whites for acid (Option A ruled out)
  • Early endoscopy to assess severity and extent (Option B)
  • Avoid emetics and sodium bicarbonate to prevent perforation (Option C ruled out)

Management by Burn Degree

1st Degree Burns:

  • 48 hours observation; oral feeds resumed once saliva is swallowed painlessly
  • Regular follow-up endoscopy at 1st, 2nd, and 8th months to identify stricture

2nd & 3rd Degree Burns:

  • Fluid therapy, antibiotics, nutrition, PPI’s and aerosolized steroids and resuscitation
 
  • Fiberoptic-guided airway intubation/tracheostomy if necessary
  • Endoscopic esophageal stenting, jejunostomy for feeding
  • Laparoscopy for evaluation; laparotomy in unstable patients
  • Resection and end cervical esophagostomy with jejunostomy if necrosis is full thickness
  • Consider re-exploration after 36-48 hours if necessary
  • Regular endoscopic dilatation for stricture
  • Use of various dilators (e.g., balloon, Savary-Gilliard, Eder-Puestow) for esophageal dilatation

Surgical Considerations
  • Esophageal resection is technically difficult; bypass may be preferred
  • Resection and end cervical esophagostomy with jejunostomy if necrosis is full thickness
  • A colonic conduit may be used if the stomach is diseased
  • Multiple strictures may require esophageal resection and colonic transposition

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy swallowed a disk battery and an x-ray revealed that it was lodged in the esophagus. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Endoscopic removal after 1 day of observation
Endoscopic removal after 2 days of observation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Immediate endoscopic removal

 

Explanation:

The disk battery in the esophagus should be removed endoscopically as an emergency procedure. The battery can cause significant injury to the esophageal tissue within a short period, leading to serious complications.

 

Foreign body in esophagus:

Category

Indications

Management

Emergency
  • Esophageal obstruction (inability to handle oral secretions)
  • Disk batteries
  • Sharp-pointed objects

Immediate endoscopic removal (Option B)

Urgent

  • Blunt objects
  • Incomplete obstruction
  • Multiple magnets (or single magnet plus another ferromagnetic object within endoscopic reach)
  • Coins

Endoscopic removal within 12 to 24 hours (Option C ruled out)

Non Urgent
  • Objects in stomach >2.5cm diameter
  • Disc battery in the stomach for up to 48 hrs if asymptomatic
  • Blunt objects that fail to pass the stomach in 3-4 weeks

Observation (Option A, D ruled out)
